source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: Numerous observations have been made on specimens exposed in autoclaves at temperatures of $5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ and above. The tests were usually in highpressure steam refreshed at hourly intervals by blow down and reinjection, but one series was in oxygen at $6 . 9 \ \mathbf { M P a }$ .

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: but one series was in oxygen at $6 . 9 \ \mathbf { M P a }$ .

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: The behavior, typically in a test for $^ { 2 4 } \textbf { h }$ at $5 5 0 \mathrm { { \circ C } }$ , $6 . 9 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ , in steam, varied from the formation of lustrous black nodule-free oxide, through the development of occasional discrete nodules, to the growth of continuous or heavily spalling white oxide films.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: Different batches of Zircaloy-2 nominally similar in all respects gave different numbers and sizes of nodules.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk3

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk7

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk7

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk7
evidence_span: The amounts of hydrogen taken-up, however, are small, representing less than 5 percent for many materials

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_020_chunk7
evidence_span: Extrapolation of results to the expected full reactor life indicates that neither loss of section by corrosion nor hydrogen pick-up by the pressure tube should be lifelimiting
